comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] Your link doesn't work. It's en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Morgenthau_Sr. (you always must insert the dot after "Sr" manually)

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: A report about his arrival is in The New York Times, February 23, 1916

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: "Cleveland Hoadley Dodge (January 26, 1860 - June 24, 1926), was a capitalist and philanthropist who was active in New York City politics. He was President of Phelps Dodge, and served as "adviser and financier" to Woodrow Wilson. He was known for his charity work in World War I." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Hoadley_Dodge

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Samuel Train Dutton (October 1849 in Hillsboro NH - March 28, 1919 in Atlantic City), educator and active in many organizations for human welfare. He was professor at Columbia University (according to the obituary in The New York Times, March 29, 1919). His biography is in www.forgottenbooks.org/books/Samuel_Train_Dutton_1000071407 (some pages are unavailable to free members)

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Dodge was treasurer of the New York Committee for Armenian and Syrian Relief, Morgenthau and Dutton were members (and founders), see advertising in the New-York tribune., November 03, 1917, Page 7 "You Won't let Me Starve, Will You". See also www.genocide-museum.am/eng/online_exhibition_10.php

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: A biographical sketch of Dutton, written on the occasion of his death in 1919, in the Teachers College (Columbia University) Record: books.google.com/books?id=4PABAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA276&...
